history.content:
If you mean 128AB and 228AB, then no, to my understanding. x28 sequence mainly deals with basics of numerical analysis and numerical DE. Although 128A is boarder and may mention some numerical linear algebra, it is only direct solver (Gaussian elimination?) for linear systems, and I believe nobody cares about it (who will solve a linear system in computers directly nowadays?). It just "literally" scratches the surface of topics (and it is not fun based on my experience). 228B, numerical DE, or PDE, is really fun, but not related to ML in any way. But I highly recommend it because it is pretty fun~ and it is not a typical math graduate course with incomprehensible textbooks and "It is obvious/trivial" proofs.

221 (numerical linear algebra) should be important for ML, I am not sure because I don't know much about ML, but I guess it should useful, at the very least you could reinforce your linear algebra skill. Also analysis is important! 104/105/202AB is not directly related to ML, but if you want to understand probability theory, analysis is one of the most important tools. And probability is definitely important for ML.

I guess upper div stat classes are more useful for ML?

children.subject:
I've only taken real analysis and parts of abstract algebra, but I've thought about this question before, so I'll drop some of my thoughts here.

I think it depends what you're looking to do exactly within machine learning. If you are looking to do more math-related research, it might be good to understand the basic structures introduced in abstract algebra. For instance, even the relatively non-mathy paper on the popular embedding method GloVe mentions groups and homomorphisms.

More familiarity with linear algebra would always be useful, but it might be a better use of time to optimize intuition toward particular concepts, such as SVD.

I haven't taken numerical analysis, but I would assume that it's a core class if you're looking to work with dynamics in a continuous domain and then transfer your findings into a discrete algorithm that can be run in a practical, computational setting. Plus, next semester's 128A is being taught by Strain, who seems to run an interesting, but also difficult, 128A.

More generally, I think taking upper div math will be useful in developing mathematical intuition and rigor. If you don't enjoy math and are solely looking for applications to machine learning, taking upper div math courses may not be a good route.

Another segment of courses that could be very useful to applications in machine learning is optimization. The EECS undergrad and grad courses in optimization would be very useful. There's also Math 170 taught by Evans, which is a relatively light class with a fun professor. However, Math 170 certainly would not be as useful to machine learning as the EECS courses would be.

I also agree with Yimin that stats might be more directly useful for machine learning.

Confirming that Math 221 is great background for anyone who want to get into machine learning in a serious way.

An introductory numerical analysis course is good for anyone who will someday do research in machine learning, but not as important as numerical linear algebra.  Courses in PDEs (numerical or analytical) are probably not relevant, except at some of the bleedingest-edge niche ML research frontiers.

All this is assuming you have an intuitive mastery of basic linear algebra, which ought to be your first priority.

history.content:
I couldn't get into CS189 nor CS182, so I looked to the math department and found this interesting course. How useful is it to ML? Thanks.

On that note, what upper div math courses are useful for ML. Abstract Algebra, Numerical analysis, linear algebra (i am guessing this one is yes?), am I missing any?
history.subject: How useful is Numerical Analysis to Machine learning?
